newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australia miner sees copper costs under 60c/lb.
newsitem.headline: Australia miner sees copper costs under 60c/lb.

text.p: MIM Holdings Ltd said on Sunday it expected production costs from its A$290 million Enterprise copper mine extension at Mount Isa to average less than US$0.60 a pound by about 1999.

"It's high grade, it's deep, but with the technology we have we think we can achieve a very satisfactory cost position at Isa, which I think reflects the quality of that ore body," MIM's managing director Nick Stump told the Nine Network's Business Sunday programme.
MIM typically keeps its production costs a secret, although analysts have estimated they are running at about US$0.71 a pound at the current deposit being mined at Mount Isa.
This compares with costs of US$0.40 a pound or less among some of the lowest-cost producers.

Asked if Mount Isa was making losses, Stump said the mine was operating "about break even at this time," but added "it was really hard to tell", due to copper prices and the Australian dollar exchange rate.
In August, MIM reported a net profit after abnormals for the year to June 30 of A$170.6 million, but said the Mount Isa operations recorded a loss in June.

The stronger the local currency, the less funds MIM can repatriate from U.S. dollar-denominated export sales, while each one U.S. cent change in the copper price on a per pound basis means A$3.77 million to the company's bottom line.
"Last week we had a US$0.85 (per pound) copper price and a US$0.80 exchange rate," Stump said.
"Pretty tough, but of course this is new territory because the price has fallen faster and further than anybody expected because of the Sumitomo fiasco," Stump added.
Japanese trading house Sumitomo Corp in mid-June revealed some US$1.8 billion in losses from rogue copper trades, sending the international metal price into a tailspin.
Citing last week's sale of most of the company's oil and gas interests to Santos Ltd for A$45.1 million, Stump said a diposal programme of non-core assets was "well advanced".
Stump also said he expected development of the George Fisher zinc prospect near Mount Isa to proceed.
MIM is currently studying the feasibility of bringing the prospect on stream as zinc production at Mount Isa nears an end.
"I'm sure George Fisher will be mined," Stump said.
